direction.raw_text: I know.  Everyone went home.  We offered them refunds.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Anybody take it?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A few.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (closes his eyes) Vultures... Luke smiles.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm not happy about this, mind you, but if I have to go, at least I'm going in my own bed, the same bed my Lily died in, and... knowing that my son is alive.  That's not too shabby, is it?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're not going anywhere, Harry.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't tell me, I know about these things.  I've seen it before.  It's all right.  It's... all right. You're here.  Oh, God, I love you, son. Harry smiles.  Luke kisses his hand and leans up, whispering in Harry's ear:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And I love you... Dad. Harry smiles faintly, looks at Luke.  He nods, then closes his eyes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (softly) Oh, so... much... lighter... Slowly, Harry exhales.  His face relaxes, completely at peace.  He doesn't breathe again. Luke looks at Harry's face for a moment.  Then as the tears well up, he leans over and ever-so-gently places a kiss on Harry's forehead.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We commit to the earth the mortal remains of Harry Bernard Trumbo, safe in the knowledge that his immortal soul is at peace and at last reunited with his beloved Lillian in the bosom of the Lord. Let us pray. Everyone bows their heads.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: "The Lord is my shepherd, I shall not want, he maketh me to lie down in green pastures..." Luke looks up at the sky, then steps forward and lays a single rose on Harry's casket.  Then, as everyone surreptitiously watches, he turns and walks away from the gravesite, toward the cemetery entrance. Adele watches Luke depart... ANOTHER ANGLE ... and she's not alone.  Agents Saunders and Brett are watching everything from their car, which is parked nearby. As Luke walks away, Saunders snaps his photo with a long-lens camera...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mind if I join you? Luke looks up, squinting.  Adele stands above him, backlit by the golden light of the sundown.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sure. She sits next to him.  Tentatively, she touches his shoulder. He leans into her, and she enfolds her arm in his. Pause.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Your father said... that I would start to remember things. Suddenly, Adele feels as though she's walking on eggshells.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (slowly) What... do you remember?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well... everything.  It started coming back a couple of days ago. I remember everything now.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I see...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Delly.  I'm... I'm not... Harry wasn't my father.  And I'm not... I'm not Luke. She closes her eyes.  All her suspicions are suddenly confirmed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (adrift) Oh... Her tears start, and she moves to hug Luke -- but instead, she starts hitting him, flailing, beating on his chest.  He hugs her tightly, and she completely lets go.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (crying) Oh, god, I knew!  I knew!  I knew from the start!  I wanted you to be Luke!  I wanted you to be alive! You're so much like him, you have no idea.  No wonder everyone else accepted you!  You don't know what you -- what Luke meant to this town, suddenly being alive!  You don't know what this town lost! You just don't know... She pulls away, stands, and looks him in the eye.  Luke rises.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (sobbing uncontrollably) I knew you weren't Luke!  And I tried not to fall in love with you! And... I don't even know your name! Oh, god... Luke moves toward her.  She backs away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I fell in love with you, too, Delly.  Only now I don't know how I feel, about you or about anything. I only think I know how Luke would feel. She's still sobbing.  He moves to her, takes her in his arms.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Delly, shhhhhh...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (pulling away) No... I can't... I have to... I can't... She runs off, crying... DISSOLVE TO: INT.  MABEL'S DINER - DAY ON SHERIFF ELDRIDGE, making short work of a steak and eggs.  As he powers down his meal, Agents Saunders and Brett, distinctly out-of-place in their dark suits and hats, enter the diner.  They take note of Eldridge, and come over.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Are you the sheriff?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And I got the uniform to prove it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm Special Agent Walter Saunders, this is Special Agent Steven Brett,
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: . TERWILLIGER
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . TERWILLIGER
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: : INT.  HARRY'S BEDROOM - NIGHT Harry is in bed, eyes closed.  Doc Lardner has a stethoscope to his chest.  He leans up and pats Harry's hand. He stands and comes over to Luke and Adele, who are near the door.  Just outside, angling for a view into the room, are Old Tim and Mrs. Terwilliger.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: : EXT.  LAWSON CEMETERY - DAY It's a beautiful, bright, sunny day.  Luke and Adele stand at the front of the large group of mourners.  REVEREND COLEMAN, 50s, conducts the service.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: : THE BASE OF THE WAR MEMORIAL, and Luke's name inscribed there. EXT.  CITY HALL SQUARE - DUSK Luke stands in front of the memorial, head bowed.  After a moment, he sits, leaning against the memorial. ON LUKE Lost in thought, he buries his face in his hands.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: .  May we have a word with you? They flash identification, which Eldridge notes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (gesturing) Please, sit. They sit across from Eldridge.  As Saunders speaks, Agent Brett pulls a photo from his coat pocket.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A couple of days ago, a county flood control maintenance crew pulled a car out of the Lawson Wash ocean outlet.  They checked its registration, and when the owner was identified, they notified us. Agent Brett slides the photo toward Eldridge. ON THE PHOTO It's Peter Appleton -- Luke.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (smiling) Well, that'd be Luke Trumbo.  Looks like you boys've solved a little mystery we've had going on for a few months.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sir, that's a photo of man named Peter Appleton.  He's been missing from Los Angeles for close to three months now.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What?  No, there's got to be a...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sheriff -- this man is a suspected communist.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Am I under arrest? Eldridge glances at Agent Saunders, who stares at Pete impassively.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, no, but these gentlemen would like to get some answers...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't know what else to tell you. I wasn't hiding out.  I hit my head and I didn't remember anything until a few days ago.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Now that you remember who you are, were you planning on telling anyone your true identity?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I already have.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Who?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: My girlfriend.  If she still is...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (checking his notebook) Would that be Miss Sinclair?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (ironic smile) No.  No, not Miss Sinclair.  I'm talking about Adele Lardner. Agent Saunders glances at Eldridge.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The doctor's daughter.  She was Luke Trumbo's sweetheart. Pause.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mr. Appleton, I have reason to believe you're holding something back, and that just rubs me the wrong way. (pause) Sir, are you a communist?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (firmly) No.  Absolutely not.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: All right.  All right.  We'll see.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Let's close up. As Mrs. Terwilliger and Old Tim silently shamble off, Pete goes over and flips OFF several light switches.  Most of the theater goes dark.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Who's that?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's me. Adele climbs onto the roof, comes over and sits down next to Pete.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hi.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hi. Pause.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm sure a lot of people down in L.A. are worried sick about you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah?  I'm sure a lot more people down in L.A. want a piece of me. He turns to her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This Luke was a pretty good guy, wasn't he?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (wistful smile) Oh, yes.  Yes, he was.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well... let me tell you, I'm not Luke.  I know who I am now, and you don't.  And... I don't like me very much.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (changing the subject) You know, it's going to take me a while to get used to calling you Pete. (she takes it for a spin) Pete.  Pete.  It's a nice name.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thanks, I like it.  I think. Pause.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Delly, I want to do the right thing. Pete can't believe he just said that -- but he did.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I believe you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The truth is, I'm a lot of things, but communist isn't one of them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But if you only went to one meeting, why does anyone care? Besides, why should it even matter if you were a communist?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Come on, Delly, look at the country today.  We're fighting communists in Korea, we're paranoid about the Russians, we've got this thing with the Rosenbergs and the atomic bomb... (bitterly) You think they want "suspected communists" entertaining the American public with party propaganda like, gosh I don't know, "Sand Pirates of the Sahara?"
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Forget about all that.  You want to do the right thing?  Then defend your name.  If someone says something about you that's untrue, you have to stand up and say so.  I know the law, and the law's on your side. Beat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What about you, Delly?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I am, too. Pete smiles and puts his arms around her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You'll stand by me?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Whatever happens. They kiss, and we
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Whatsit, girl? He stops -- he hears something, too -- a LOW RUMBLE.  Lottie starts BARKING.  The RUMBLE is getting LOUDER.  Rory's getting worried.  He looks at THE FOG BANK. It's starting to GLOW from within.  Lottie's barking gets LOUDER and angrier.  Suddenly, a large black car punches out of the fog bank and tears down the road.  It's followed by another, and another -- and perhaps a dozen more cars and trucks, all heading hell-bent-for-leather toward the town. Rory moves toward Lottie, trying to quiet her as the cars fly past the station.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Shhhhh.  I know, Lottie.  This time, I thought it was the Martians for sure.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm here with Mabel Lanier, the owner of the diner here on Commerce Street where Appleton often took meals.  Mrs. Lanier, tell me, what are your thoughts about having such a celebrated suspected communist in your midst all this time?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, its kinds hard to believe, 'cause Luke -- I mean Peter -- is such a... I mean, since he's been back, I've never seen the town so happy and all.  It's like he gave us some... I don't know... some hope, I guess.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What she's referring to folks, is yet another bizarre twist in this story.  Not only is Appleton alive, but he's been suffering from amnesia and living here in Lawson, where, due to a startling resemblance, everyone in town for the last three months has taken him for one of Lawson's dead war heroes, Albert Trumbo...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (a catch in her voice) Luke.  We always called him Luke. Mabel glances at Bob, who lowers his head.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The FBI can't arrest you, because you haven't done anything wrong.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, that's a relief.  I understand they usually don't let that stop them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: However... you're gonna be subpoenaed to testify before the Un-American Activities Committee when they open hearings in Los Angeles.  Now, if you play ball and tell them what they want to hear, they'll clear you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And I won't be a communist anymore.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Exactly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So it doesn't make any difference that I'm not one now, and have never been one. Leo stands and walks to the window.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kid, don't get philosophical with me.  This is a game, but it's not your game.  You play by their rules, or they'll ruin you.  And they have the power to do it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Doesn't it bother anyone that this is a perversion of democracy? Leo turns to her and smiles.  His tone is charmingly matter- of-factly, not condescending in the least.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Darling, don't kid yourself.  We don't have a "democracy" in this country.  The Declaration of Independence?  The Constitution? These are pieces of paper with signatures on 'em.  And you know what a piece of paper with a signature is?  It's a contract. And you know what a contract is? Something that can be re-negotiated at any time.  It just so happens that the House Un-American Activities Committee is re- negotiating the contract this time around. Leo takes out a cigarette, lights it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Next time, it might be the FBI. The time after that, it might be the President.  But it'll always be someone.  Count on it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's not the country Luke fought for.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Lest we forget, Peter, your own military career was somewhat less illustrious than Luke's.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's wrong, Leo.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Peter, don't let that stop you all of a sudden. Leo pulls a folded paper from his coat pocket and hands it to Pete.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Here.  When you're called, read this to them.  Just tell the bastards what they want to hear, and we can all get on with our lives. There's a knock at the door.  Leo opens it.  Standing there is a small MAN wearing a serious suit and an even more serious fedora.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Peter Appleton?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (standing) You found him. The Man reaches into his breast pocket and withdraws a blue backed folded document, which he hands to Pete.  As he does, a FLASH lights the room. At the door, a pair of PHOTOGRAPHERS and a NEWSREEL CAMERAMAN are jockeying for position.  Pete rolls his eyes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Peter Appleton, you are hereby subpoenaed to appear as a witness before a special session of the House Committee on Un-American Activities.  You are to appear in Los Angeles, California, at the Biltmore Hotel, at the date and time specified herein. Pete takes the subpoena.  There's an awkward moment, as the newsreel camera is still rolling.  Pete cradles the subpoena like an Oscar statuette and smiles into the lens.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ("on") This is a great honor.  I'll treasure this always.  Thank you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (softly)
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: : INT.  SHERIFF'S OFFICE - DAY (Oh, and by the way, from here on, he's PETE again.) Pete sits across from Eldridge, Saunders and Brett.  The silence in the room is thick.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: : EXT.  SHERIFF'S STATION - DAY Pete comes out into the bright midday sun.  It takes a moment for his eyes to adjust, and when they do, he becomes aware of perhaps TWENTY PEOPLE lining the sidewalk in front of the station. PETE'S POV We recognize several of the people.  Carl Leffert.  Bob Leffert and Mabel Lanier.  Daley Thornhill.  Katie Rutherford.  Stanton Lawson.  Now, there's nothing in the least bit threatening about the gathering -- and that's what's so disturbing about it.  They're not an angry mob, they're just standing there, running the gamut of emotions. Shock.  Disillusionment.  Betrayal. It's an awkward moment.  Pete doesn't quite know how to react.  He wants to go over and talk to them, but he wouldn't know what to say.  He wishes one of them would talk to him, just say something, anything.  But no one does. Then, Bob Leffert turns away from Pete.  He shoves his hook hand into his pocket and sullenly moves away, followed by Mabel, then his brother, then the others... ... leaving Pete alone.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: : INT.  BIJOU LOBBY - NIGHT Old Tim, in his doorman's uniform, stands by the open, empty door. Mrs. Terwilliger, behind the candy counter, wipes up an imaginary spill, a full wheel of unsold tickets by her elbow. Pete anxiously paces the lobby.  He looks into THE AUDITORIUM. Every seat is empty. He glances at his watch, then turns to Old Tim and Mrs. Terwilliger:
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: : EXT.  THE BIJOU SIGN - NIGHT Pete sits leaning up against the base of the dark sign.  A gentle breeze tousles his hair as he gazes up at the stars. After a moment, he HEARS footsteps coming up the ladder to the roof.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: : EXT.  RORY'S GAS STATION - MORNING There's a thick bank of coastal fog just down the road, obscuring any view of the ocean a mile away.  It's deadly quiet as gas station owner RORY, late 60s, pulls up and parks his Model A truck.  He gets out, and an big old German Shepherd, LOTTIE, jumps out of the truck bed. Rory moves to the door, and is about to put his key in the lock, when Lottie starts whining, looking toward the fog bank and sniffing the air expectantly.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: : EXT.  COMMERCE STREET - DAY The place is bedlam, overflowing with REPORTERS, NEWSREEL CAMERA CREWS, PHOTOGRAPHERS, you name it. A RADIO CREW is broadcasting in front of Mabel's Diner.  The REPORTER is on-the-air, hugging his microphone, speaking above the din.  Mabel stands next to him, his hand on her shoulder.  Bob Leffert stands nearby, grim.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: : INT.  BIJOU OFFICE - DAY Pete is at the desk, staring into space.  Adele leans against the radiator behind him.  The silence in the room is thick. Across the desk from Pete sits Leo Kubelsky.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: : THE SUBPOENA in a partially-packed suitcase. WIDER INT.  PETE'S BEDROOM - DAY Pete is sitting in a chair, reading the statement Leo gave him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Peter Appleton, do hereby renounce my membership in the American Communist Party, and by way of purging myself of my indiscretion, wish to provide the following names of fellow members to this committee, so that those persons may have the opportunity to do as I have done..." He scans down the page.  It's a long list.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jesus... He HEARS a "meow!" And turns to look. CAT is standing in the bedroom doorway.  He folds up and pockets the list.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Old Tim? After a moment, Old Tim appears in the doorway, wringing his knit cap in his hands.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Can I... Can I t-t-talk to you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sure.  Come on in.  I was just packing. Pete stands, gestures Old Tim to the chair, as he sits on the bed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Please, sit.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thanks. He sits.  Pause.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They'll come back, you know. They'll all c-c-come back.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The customers?  I don't know...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They will.  They w-w-will. Pete turns to Old Tim, fixes him in the eye.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tim, I have to tell you something.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's about me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh. Pause, as Pete gathers courage and tries to find the words.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm... I'm not Luke.  Luke is dead. He died in the war.  He's not coming back, and I'm not him.  I don't even belong here.  This whole thing started out as an accident, and that's all it is.  An accident.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: My name isn't Luke.  It's Peter. Peter Appleton. Old Tim stands and looks askance at Pete. Pause.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Did you think I didn't kn-kn-know that?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (taken aback) I thought you...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I know more than you give me c-c- credit, that's for sure.  Don't you see, it don't m-m-matter who you are?  All that matters is what you g-g-gave us.  And you can't take that away now.  You're wrong, Peter Appleton.  You do belong here. He leans down to Pete.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You hafta give us back the B-B- Bijou. Old Tim straightens up, nods at Pete.  Then, silently, he picks up Cat and exits.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You've got everything?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah.  Except a chance in hell of coming out of this intact.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You'll be fine.  No matter what Leo Kubelsky says, you've got a hundred and seventy-five years of American law on your side.  Don't forget that.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I wish you were coming with me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And who's gonna run the projector until you get back?  Mrs. Terwilliger?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Maybe we could train Cat to run the projector.  You know, a system of scratching posts, and gears, and levers... They both smile as the train's HORN blows.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Board! Pete picks up his suitcase and they walk toward the passenger compartment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Did you bring along something to read?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Damn... Adele pulls a pocket-sized leather-bound book out of her purse and hands it to Pete.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I didn't think so.  Here.  This is mine, you can borrow it. INSERT - THE BOOK Well-worn and scuffed, nevertheless the title is clear:
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: : EXT.  LAWSON PASSENGER DEPOT - DAY Pete and Adele walk slowly down the platform toward the waiting train.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Pete looks at the book, then at Adele.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Not exactly light reading, I know. Believe it or not, I've read this since high school, and it got me all the way through law school. Besides, there's something in there that'll help you.  You won't have to get very far, it's near the beginning.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (clearly touched) Delly... thanks, thank you.  I'll take good care of this.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Just remember two things.  First, the law is a living thing.  It made us free and it keeps us free. Sometimes it gets twisted around by people for their own purposes. Sometimes it makes mistakes, sometimes big mistakes.  But in the end, the law prevails for the just. Sometimes, it takes a while.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Okay.  What's the second thing? She thinks for a moment.  She needs the right words.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'll be here... if you come back. The train pulls out.  Adele and Pete exchange waves as we
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's perfect, Dad.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The committee and the chamber will come to order. Lardner forces a smile at Mrs. Terwilliger and Old Tim.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (sweating and wincing) This television's a grand little invention, isn't it? INT.  BILTMORE HOTEL GRAND BALLROOM - DAY DOYLE The agenda for this morning's special session of the House Committee on Un-American Activities shows a number of witnesses, and I'd like to admonish those that are here to view the testimony of our first witness to keep order at all times, or this chamber will be closed.  I'm referring especially to the ladies and gentlemen of the press.  I hope that's clear. Beat.  Doyle scans the room.  He clearly means business.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Call Peter Appleton. All eyes and cameras swing toward the door. ON PETE As he enters the chamber, dozens of FLASHBULBS fire as every eye and every camera follows him silently to his seat.  As he sits, he glances behind him. PETE'S POV Leo Kubelsky is sitting in the front row of spectators.  He smiles and nods at Pete. Pete doesn't acknowledge him, and turns back.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The witness will please stand and raise his right hand. Pete does as instructed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Do you swear that the testimony you are about to give before this committee of the United States House of Representatives will be the truth, the whole truth, and nothing but the truth, so help you god?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I do.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Be seated and state your full name and place of residence for the record.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Peter Kenneth Appleton.  Hollywood, California.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The chair notes that you are appearing without the benefit of counsel today, Mr. Appleton.  We certainly hope this means that you intend to be fully forthcoming with this committee?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (faint smile) I'll do my best, Mr. Chairman.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Now, we're informed that you have a statement you'd like to read, is that correct?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (innocently) A statement? Doyle and Clyde exchange glances.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes.  A prepared statement.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Um... no.  I don't have a statement at this time. Pete turns in his chair and winks at Leo.  Leo rolls his eyes and shakes his head. INT.  LARDNER LIVING ROOM - DAY Adele breathes a sigh of relief.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I think he's doing very well, so far.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They haven't called out the dogs yet.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Very well then, the questions will be asked by the Majority Counsel, Mr. Clyde. The TV shot swings to see Elvin Clyde.  He puts on his glasses and fixes Pete with an oily grin.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I spoke too soon.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thank you Mr. Chairman, and thank you Mr. Appleton, for appearing today. INT.  BILTMORE HOTEL GRAND BALLROOM - DAY CLYDE Mr. Appleton, you mention that your home is Hollywood, California.  But isn't it true that for the last several months, you've made your home in a town called Lawson, California?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sir, that is true.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mr. Appleton, do you know an "Albert Lucas Trumbo?"
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Luke Trumbo?  We never met.  But I'd like to think I know him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Is that because you were masquerading as Luke Trumbo while you were in Lawson?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mr. Clyde you're twisting things around.  I wasn't masquerading. Luke Trumbo... Luke was a good man who gave his life for his country. I just... happen to look a little bit like him.  That's all.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (referring to notes) Yes, I see that Private Trumbo was reported missing in action and is presumed dead.  I also see that you were posted stateside during the war.  Fort Dix?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, sir.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, I'm sure we're all glad to see you came through it all right. A few spectators titter. INT.  MABEL'S DINER - DAY Mabel and Bob listen to the hearing on a radio in the packed diner.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Now, I see that you've been running a movie theater in Lawson called "The Bijou," is that also true?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes sir.  But I didn't go to Lawson to run The Bijou, that was... that was something that just happened. You see, I was involved in an accident in Lawson, and I spent some time recovering there. INT.  BILTMORE HOTEL GRAND BALLROOM - DAY Clyde holds up copies of the Los Angeles Examiner and Los Angeles Times with Pete's picture on the front page.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Anyone who reads the newspaper is quite familiar with your... "accident," Mr. Appleton.  An accident which, conveniently, came hard upon your dismissal from United Pictures.  Tell us, this "accident" of yours, are we given to understand that it affected your memory?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And what is the state of your memory now? Beat.  Pete smiles.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm sorry, what was the question? The audience LAUGHS.  Clyde nods at Pete, forces a tight smile.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We... appreciate... your little note of levity, Mr. Appleton, but this is a very serious matter, and it merits your fullest attention. (back to business) That state of your memory now, Mr. Appleton? INT.  WYATT'S HARDWARE - DAY Avery Wyatt listens to the hearing on a store radio.  Spencer comes around the paint aisle, wiping his hands on his apron. He moves to the radio and listens solemnly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sir, are you referring to the fact that I was suffering from amnesia, and I've since recovered my memory? INT.  BILTMORE HOTEL GRAND BALLROOM - DAY CLYDE (impatient) I'm interested in knowing if you remember things you did in your past, or if they've been conveniently "blotted out" as a result of your "accident."
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (smiling) Mr. Clyde, I remember everything.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Good.  Good. (holds up a piece of paper) Now, I hold in my hand a photostatic copy of the attendance roster for the "Bread Instead of Bullets Club" of the University of California, Los Angeles, dated October 11, 1935.  A copy of this paper is before you, Mr. Appleton. Do you recognize it? Pete looks on the table and finds the roster.  He's surprised to see it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes... yes, I do.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Referring to line thirty-seven of the document, does your printed name and signature appear there?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes it does.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mr. Appleton, please tell this committee what was the nature and purpose of the "Bread Instead of Bullets Club?"
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mr. Clyde, do you want to know what I knew then, or do you want to know what I know now?  They're two different things?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Start with what you knew then.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, I'd direct the attention of counsel and committee to line thirty-six of the document, and the name printed and signed there.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We see it.  For the record, it reads "Lucille Angstrom."  What's the point of this?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, that's what I knew then.  Or who I knew, I should say.  You see, I was trying to court Miss Angstrom.  I went to the meeting to impress her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (grinning) Are you asking this committee to believe that you attended a meeting of a communist party front organization in order to impress a girl?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (slyly) Well, if you'd seen Miss Angstrom... The audience LAUGHS.  Doyle BANGS his gavel.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You asked for the truth.  That's the truth.  I had no idea what the meeting was about.  I just sat through it so I could be near her. I'm sure even a Majority Counsel like yourself is familiar with the concept of impressing a girl. The audience LAUGHS.  Clyde shoots a look at Doyle, who BANGS his gavel.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Chamber will come to order. Clyde shuffles some papers and looks back at Pete.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: All right, Mr. Appleton.  That was what you knew then.  What do you know now?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (takes a deep breath) Well, I know that I lost my job because of one meeting I went to when I was a kid in college.  I know that I've been branded a communist, which I'm not, but even if I was, it shouldn't matter, or what do we have a Bill Of Rights for?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mr. Chairman, the witness is being non-responsive... A few members of the audience APPLAUD.  As Pete speaks, their numbers grow.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (passionately) I know that a lot of good, honest, decent people, people that I consider my true friends, feel betrayed by me, not because of who and what I am, but because of what you say I am!  I know that I... Doyle BANGS his gavel several times.  Pete stops and the room falls quiet.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (emphatically) Mr. Appleton, you will respond to the questions of this committee without elaboration or speechmaking, or the chair will find you in Contempt Of Congress. You will not be warned again, is that clear? (he lets this sink in, then) Continue, Mr. Clyde.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (looking down at his desk) Mr. Appleton... Clyde takes a long pause for effect, then looks up at Pete.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Are you now, or have you ever been, a member of the communist party?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, sir.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (holding up the roster) Are you refuting this evidence and your previous testimony?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm not refuting anything.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yet you're contradicting yourself. You earlier testified that you attended a meeting of a communist party-run organization, yet you just said, under oath, that you were not now -- nor ever -- a member of the communist party.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's not a contradiction at all, sir.  I went to the meeting, but I didn't go as a member.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, then, as what did you go? Beat.  Pete smiles.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm a little hesitant to say.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The witness need not be hesitant to say anything before this committee, as long as it's the truth. Pete shifts in his chair, then leans into the microphone.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, I went as... a horny young man. The chamber erupts in LAUGHTER.  Even the other COMMITTEE MEMBERS are laughing, except Clyde and Doyle, who BANGS his gavel vigorously. INT.  SHERIFF'S OFFICE - DAY Sheriff Eldridge and Daley Thornhill listen to the hearing on the radio.  They are both laughing at Pete's last comment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Damn, he don't wanna spar with these boys.  They'll eat him alive. INT.  BILTMORE HOTEL GRAND BALLROOM - DAY The room settles.  Doyle wags his finger accusingly at Pete.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (angry) Mr. Appleton, you are making light of a legally constituted committee of the United States Congress. Believe you me, you do not want to incur our wrath.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (matter-of-factly) I'm sorry, sir, I have no intention of making light of this committee. And I have no intention of incurring your wrath, Mr. Chairman. I have a few friends who have already incurred your wrath. They've sent me letters from jail.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (interrupting) Mr. Chairman!  Mr. Chairman, the witness is making another speech. I would ask that Mr. Appleton be admonished...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (indifferent) Mr. Appleton, there is no question before you at this time, but I'm sure Mr. Clyde has plenty more prepared, and if you'd like to either answer them or plead the Fifth Amendment, we can at least get on with the business of this committee. INT.  LARDNER LIVING ROOM - DAY Adele moves to within inches of the TV screen.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tell them Pete.  Tell them...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (wrestling with this) Mr. Chairman, as I understand it, the Fifth Amendment pertains to self-incrimination, and I can't incriminate myself because I've done nothing wrong.  Besides, incrimination is why you have Mr. Clyde working for you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mr. Chairman... INT.  BILTMORE HOTEL GRAND BALLROOM - DAY Clyde is still protesting, but Doyle waves him off.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well then, Mr. Appleton, just what is your intention? Pete's sweating under the lights.  He's bluffed his last bluff, and he's on the ropes.  He reaches into his pocket... and takes out the prepared statement. INT.  LARDNER LIVING ROOM - DAY PETE (ON TV) I... Mr. Chairman, I have a prepared statement I'd like to read... ADELE Her hand goes to her mouth.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, Pete.  No... INT.  BILTMORE HOTEL GRAND BALLROOM - DAY DOYLE Go ahead, Mr. Appleton.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (slowly reading)
direction.name: direction

result.heading: CONSTITUTION OF THE UNITED STATES ANNOTATED EDITION

dialogue.raw_text: : INT.  BILTMORE HOTEL GRAND BALLROOM (LOS ANGELES) - DAY The House Committee on Un-American Activities has effectively taken over the Grand Ballroom of this magnificent hotel, and the joint is packed to the rafters.  Members of the AUDIENCE crane their necks to see out into the hallway, from where the witnesses will be entering. The COMMITTEE MEMBERS are seated at their dais, brightly lit by the dozens of newsreel and TV lights.  Elvin Clyde is seated at the far right.  Dead center of the dais is the Chairman, CONGRESSMAN T. JOHNSTON DOYLE of Wisconsin, a husky man in his late 50s.  He SLAMS his gavel down several times and the room goes quiet -- the talking stops, and the cameras start whirring. INT.  LARDNER LIVING ROOM - DAY Adele's in a chair, eyes glues to the TV set.  Mrs. Terwilliger and Old Tim sit on the couch, watching attentively. Doc Lardner's in a straight-backed chair at a jaunty angle to the set, holding the rabbit ears uncomfortably high aloft.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . TERWILLIGER
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Peter Appleton, do hereby..." He stops suddenly.  Pause.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mr. Appleton?  Mr. Appleton?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ... I need a drink of water.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Go ahead, son. Pete fills a glass from the pitcher.  Nervously, he spills a bit, and is splashes onto his coat.  As some of the spectators chuckle, Pete brushes the water off.  He reaches into his pocket, and pulls out Adele's copy of the constitution.  The cover is wet.  He wipes it off and sets it down on the table. He takes a sip of water.  Looks at the book.  Picks it up. Pete's terrified, but in control.  He speaks slowly -- he's making this up and thinking it out as he goes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mr. Chairman... there's... another Amendment... that I'd like to invoke at this time, but it's not the Fifth Amendment.  I wonder if you're familiar with it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mr. Appleton, you will... He opens the book and reads, tentatively at first.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: "Congress shall make no law respecting an establishment of religion, or prohibiting the free exercise thereof; or abridging the freedom of speech, or of the press; or the right of the people peaceably to assemble, and to petition the Government for a redress of grievances." Pause.  Silence in the room. ADELE She's smiling at the TV.  Her eyes are filled with tears. PETE He looks up at Chairman Doyle.  Now fully confident.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's the First Amendment, Mr. Chairman.  It's the backbone of this nation.  It's everything that gives us the potential to be right and good and just -- if only we'd live up to that potential.  It's what gives me the right to sit in this chair and say my piece before this committee without fear.  It's the most important part of the contract that every citizen has with this country.  And even though this contract... (he holds up the book) ... the Constitution and the Bill of Rights -- even though they're just pieces of paper with signatures on them -- they're the only contracts we have that are most definitely not subject to renegotiation.  Not by you, Mr. Chairman, not by you, Mr. Clyde, not by any member of this committee
direction.name: direction
